workflow.name: Full-cycle invoice automation: Airtable, QuickBooks & Stripe
workflow.description:
# This n8n template from [Intuz](https://www.intuz.com/) provides a complete and automated solution for full-cycle invoicing, orchestrating a seamless flow between Airtable, QuickBooks, and Stripe. 

This is the ultimate sales-to-cash automation. When a deal in Airtable is marked "Approved for Invoicing," this workflow intelligently syncs customer data across QuickBooks and Stripe (creating them if they don't exist), generates an official QuickBooks invoice, creates a Stripe payment link, and then updates the original Airtable record with all the new IDs and links. Eliminate manual data entry and keep your systems perfectly in sync.


## Who's this workflow for? 

1. Finance, Accounting, and Operations Teams
2. SalesOps and RevOps Teams
3. Small Business Owners and Founders
4. Agencies and Freelancers


## How It Works:
**1. Airtable Trigger & Approval Gate:** The workflow starts when a record in your Airtable base is updated. An If node immediately checks if the Status field is set to "Approved for Invoicing." If not, the workflow for that item stops.

**2. Customer Sync (QuickBooks & Stripe):**
- The workflow searches for the customer in both QuickBooks and Stripe using the details from Airtable.
- Using If nodes, it intelligently checks if the customer exists. If a customer is not found in either platform, it creates a new one. This "find-or-create" logic prevents duplicate records.

**3. Update Airtable with IDs:** Once the customer IDs from both QuickBooks and Stripe are secured (either found or newly created), the workflow updates the original Airtable record with these new IDs for future reference.

**4. Generate Financials:**
- Stripe Payment Link: It sends an HTTP request to Stripe to create a unique, ready-to-use payment link for the specified amount.
- QuickBooks Invoice: It fetches your product list from QuickBooks, finds the matching item from the Airtable record, and generates a formal, detailed invoice.

**5. Close the Loop**: In the final step, the workflow updates the Airtable record one last time to:
- Add the QuickBooks Invoice #.
- Add the Stripe Payment Link.
- Change the Status to "Invoiced."


##  Step-by-Step Setup Instructions
This is an advanced workflow. Follow these setup steps carefully.

**1. Connect Your Credentials**
- Airtable: Create and connect a Personal Access Token with data.records:read and data.records:write scopes.
- QuickBooks: Connect your QuickBooks Online account using OAuth2 credentials.
- Stripe: Connect your Stripe account using your Secret Key.

**2. Airtable Base Setup (Crucial)**
Your Airtable base must have a table with the following columns. The names must match exactly:

- Deal Name (Text)
- Client Name (Text)
- Client Email (Email)
- Status (Single-select with options: Draft,
- Approved for Invoicing, Invoiced)
- QuickBooks Customer ID (Text)
- Stripe Customer ID (Text)
- Stripe Payment Link (URL)
- QuickBooks Invoice # (Text)
- Stripe Price Id (Text - The API ID of your price in Stripe, e.g., price_123...)
- Quantity (Number)
- Quickbooks Product Name (Text)
- Created (Created Time) - This is used by the trigger.

**3. Configure the n8n Nodes**
- All Airtable Nodes: In each Airtable node, select your Base and Table from the dropdown lists.
- Get all Quickbook products (HTTP Request Node):
You must replace {YOUR_QUICKBOOKS_COMPANY_ID} in the URL with your actual QuickBooks Company ID (also known as a Realm ID).

**4. Activate the Workflow**
Save the workflow and toggle the Active switch to "on". The workflow will now trigger whenever the Created field is updated for a record in your Airtable base.


## Customization Guidance
- Changing the Trigger Status: If you use a different status than "Approved for Invoicing," simply update the value in the "IF - Status Check" node.
- Modifying Invoice Details: You can customize the Description or other line item details in the "Create an invoice" (QuickBooks) node by pulling more fields from your Airtable record.
- Adding Email Notifications: To notify a customer when their invoice is ready, add a Gmail or SendGrid node after the last Airtable Update node. You can include the Stripe Payment Link and a PDF of the QuickBooks invoice directly in the email.
- Advanced Error Handling: For a production environment, consider connecting the false output of the various IF nodes or using the .onError() workflow setting to send a Slack or email alert if a customer can't be found or an API call fails.


## Support
For further support, or to develop a custom workflow, reach out to:

- Website: https://www.intuz.com/services
- Email: getstarted@intuz.com
- LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/intuz
- Get Started: https://n8n.partnerlinks.io/intuz

## For Custom Worflow Automation
Click here- [Get Started](https://www.intuz.com/get-started)

parameters.CustomerRef: ={{ $('Update Quickbooks and Stripe Customer Ids').item.json.fields['QuickBooks Customer ID'] }}

parameters.content:
### Step 1: Airtable Trigger üö¶üìã

This node triggers the workflow whenever there is a change in the **Created** column, effectively activating when new data is added.

Why this step is important:

- ‚è∞ Automatically starts the workflow on new entries.
- üìà Monitors real-time changes for timely processing.
- üîÑ Ensures your automation responds instantly to new Airtable data.

It‚Äôs the step that keeps your workflow synced with your Airtable updates. üîî‚ú®

### Step 2: Airtable Search Records üîçüìã

This node searches and retrieves all records from a specific Airtable table.

Why this step is important:

- üîé Gathers complete data from the table for processing.
- üìä Enables further filtering, updating, or analysis within the workflow.
- üóÇÔ∏è Provides a snapshot of all relevant records at once.

It‚Äôs the step that collects your data foundation for the automation ahead. üß±‚ú®

### Step 3: Status Check (If Node) ‚úÖ‚ùå

This node checks whether the **Status** field is set to **'Approved for Invoicing'**.

- **True:** Continues with the workflow.
- **False:** Gracefully exits the workflow.

Why this step is important:

- ‚úîÔ∏è Ensures only approved records proceed for invoicing.
- üõë Prevents processing of draft or already invoiced data.
- üîÑ Maintains workflow efficiency and accuracy.

### Graceful Exit (No-Op Node) üõë‚ú®

This **No Operation** node acts as a graceful exit point for items whose status is **not** 'Approved for Invoicing'.

Why this step is important:

- üõ°Ô∏è Prevents further processing of unapproved records.
- üîÑ Ensures the workflow ends cleanly without errors.
- üßπ Keeps workflow logic clear and organized.

It‚Äôs the safe landing spot that quietly ends the flow when no action is needed. üö™‚úÖ

### Step 4: Find Customer in QuickBooks üîçüë§

This node uses the **Find Customer** operation to search for a customer in QuickBooks based on the **Display Name** parameter.

Why this step is important:

- üîé Quickly locates existing customers by their display name.
- ‚úÖ Helps avoid duplicate customer records.
- üìã Ensures accurate linking of invoices and estimates to the right customer.

It‚Äôs the step that verifies customer existence to maintain clean and organized data. üßπ‚ú®

### Step 5: Customer Existence Check (If Node) ‚ùì‚úÖ‚ùå

This node checks whether a customer exists in QuickBooks.

- **False:** Customer exists; workflow continues without creating a new customer.
- **True:** Customer does **not** exist; triggers creation of a new customer before continuing.

Why this step is important:

- üîÑ Directs the workflow to create a customer only when needed.
- üõ°Ô∏è Prevents duplicate customer entries.
- ‚öôÔ∏è Ensures smooth, logical progression of the automation.

It‚Äôs the decision point that manages customer creation intelligently. üîÄ‚ú®

Create Customer in QuickBooks ‚ûïüë§

This node uses the **Create Customer** operation to add a new customer to QuickBooks using details from Airtable.

Why this step is important:

- üÜï Adds new customers automatically when they don‚Äôt exist.
- üì• Keeps your QuickBooks customer database current and accurate.
- üîó Links customer records to subsequent invoices or estimates.

It‚Äôs the step that fills gaps in your customer list, ensuring seamless data flow. ‚úçÔ∏è‚ú®

### Step 6: Merge Customer Data Node üîóüìä

This node merges data from existing customers with newly created customer records.

Why this step is important:

- üîÑ Combines customer information into a single dataset.
- üìã Ensures continuity and completeness of customer details.
- ‚öôÔ∏è Prepares unified data for downstream workflow steps.

It‚Äôs the step that brings together all customer data for seamless processing. ü§ù‚ú®

### Step 7: Stripe Customer ID Check (If Node) üîçüí≥

This node checks whether the **Stripe Customer ID** already exists for users in Airtable.

- **True:** Stripe Customer ID exists; proceeds to find the customer.
- **False:** Stripe Customer ID does not exist; continues with the workflow to create or update as needed.

Why this step is important:

- ‚úÖ Prevents duplicate Stripe customer entries.
- üîÑ Directs the workflow along the correct path based on Stripe data.
- ‚öôÔ∏è Maintains data integrity across systems.

It‚Äôs the decision point that manages Stripe customer handling efficiently. üîÄ‚ú®

Find Customer in Stripe üîçüí≥

This node uses the **Find Customer** operation to search for a customer in Stripe based on the **Stripe Customer ID**.

Why this step is important:

- üîé Quickly locates the customer record in Stripe.
- ‚úÖ Ensures accurate synchronization between your systems.
- üìã Prevents duplicate customer creation in Stripe.

It‚Äôs the step that verifies Stripe customer existence to maintain clean and consistent billing data. üßπ‚ú®

### Step 8: Merge Stripe Customer Data Node üîóüí≥

This node merges data from the **If Node** decision with the newly retrieved customer data from the **Stripe - Find Customer** node.

Why this step is important:

- üîÑ Combines decision results with fresh customer information.
- üìä Ensures unified data for further processing in the workflow.
- ‚öôÔ∏è Maintains data consistency across Stripe and Airtable.

It‚Äôs the step that integrates conditional logic with actual customer details for smooth automation. ü§ù‚ú®

### Step 9: Stripe Customer Existence Check (If Node) üîç‚úÖ‚ùå

This node checks whether a Stripe customer exists based on the **name**.

- **True:** Customer does **not** exist; proceeds to create a new customer.
- **False:** Customer exists; continues with the workflow without creating.

Why this step is important:

- ‚úÖ Prevents duplicate Stripe customer creation.
- üîÑ Directs workflow to create customers only when necessary.
- ‚öôÔ∏è Ensures clean and accurate Stripe customer data.

It‚Äôs the decision gate that manages Stripe customer creation smartly. üîÄ‚ú®

Create Customer in Stripe ‚ûïüí≥

This node uses the **Create Customer** operation to add a new customer in Stripe using the **name** and **email address** from Airtable.

Why this step is important:

- üÜï Automatically adds new customers to Stripe when they don‚Äôt exist.
- üìß Uses accurate customer details from Airtable for Stripe records.
- üîó Ensures Stripe customer data is up-to-date and linked correctly.

It‚Äôs the step that expands your Stripe customer base seamlessly from Airtable data. ‚úçÔ∏è‚ú®

### Step 10: Merge New Stripe Customer Data Node üîóüí≥

This node merges data from the previous **If Node** with the newly created Stripe customer data.

Why this step is important:

- üîÑ Combines decision results with fresh customer creation data.
- üìä Provides a unified dataset for downstream processing.
- ‚öôÔ∏è Ensures consistency and completeness of customer information.

It‚Äôs the step that integrates newly created Stripe customer details seamlessly into the workflow. ü§ù‚ú®

### Step 11: Search Records in Airtable üîçüìã

This node searches for complete records in the Airtable table based on the **email address** from the previous merge node.

Why this step is important:

- üîé Retrieves full user data linked to the email.
- üìä Ensures accurate and updated information for the workflow.
- ‚öôÔ∏è Enables precise matching and further processing.

It‚Äôs the step that pulls detailed Airtable records to keep your automation data-rich and reliable. üìö‚ú®

nodes.name: Update Quickbooks and Stripe Customer Ids

parameters.content:
### Step 12: Update Records in Airtable ‚úèÔ∏èüîÑ

This node updates the Airtable records to add or modify the **QuickBooks Customer ID** and **Stripe Customer ID** for the corresponding users.

Why this step is important:

- üÜï Keeps Airtable data synchronized with QuickBooks and Stripe.
- üîó Ensures accurate linking of customer IDs across platforms.
- üîÑ Maintains data integrity for future workflows and reports.

It‚Äôs the step that closes the loop by updating your source data with key customer identifiers. ‚úÖ‚ú®

### Step 13: Generate Stripe Payment Link (HTTP Request) üîóüí≥

This node sends a **POST** HTTP request with the **Stripe Price ID** and **quantity** from Airtable to generate a ready-to-pay link.

Why this step is important:

- üõí Creates a payment link dynamically based on order details.
- üîó Enables easy and secure customer checkout.
- ‚ö° Automates payment initiation directly from your data.

It‚Äôs the step that turns order info into a clickable payment link, simplifying the checkout process. üî•‚ú®

### Step 14: Fetch All Products from QuickBooks (HTTP Request) üì¶üîç

This node sends an HTTP request to retrieve all products from QuickBooks.

Why this step is important:

- üìã Gathers the full product catalog for reference or processing.
- üîÑ Keeps your workflow updated with the latest product information.
- ‚öôÔ∏è Enables product data integration across your automation.

It‚Äôs the step that pulls your product inventory into the workflow for seamless management. üì¶‚ú®

### Step 15: Filter Products by Airtable Data (Code Node) ‚öôÔ∏èüîç

This node runs custom code to filter and return only the product details that exist in Airtable.

Why this step is important:

- üéØ Narrows down the product list to relevant items.
- üîÑ Improves workflow efficiency by processing only necessary data.
- üìã Ensures accuracy by matching QuickBooks products with Airtable records.

It‚Äôs the step that refines your product data for targeted automation. üßπ‚ú®

### Step 16: Create Invoice in QuickBooks üßæ‚ú®

This node uses the **Create Invoice** operation to generate an invoice in QuickBooks based on data from previous nodes.

Why this step is important:

- üìÑ Converts collected data into a formal invoice.
- üîó Links invoices to the correct customers and products.
- ‚ö° Automates billing and record-keeping processes.

It‚Äôs the step that issues the official invoice, completing the sales cycle. ‚úÖ‚ú®

nodes.name: Update Stripe Payment Link and Quickbooks Invoice #

parameters.content:
### Step 17: Update Airtable Records ‚úèÔ∏èüîÑ

This node updates Airtable records with the newly created **Stripe Payment Link** and **QuickBooks Invoice #**.

Why this step is important:

- üîó Keeps Airtable synchronized with payment and invoice details.
- üìã Provides easy access to transaction information within Airtable.
- ‚ö° Enhances tracking and reporting accuracy.

It‚Äôs the step that ensures your source data reflects the latest billing status. üìà‚ú®

### Step 18: Workflow Completion (No-Op Node) ‚úÖüéâ

This **No Operation** node marks the successful completion of the entire workflow.

Why this step is important:

- üéØ Signifies a clean and error-free end to the process.
- üõ°Ô∏è Prevents unintended actions after workflow completion.
- üîÑ Helps maintain clear workflow structure and readability.

It‚Äôs the final step that confirms your automation ran smoothly from start to finish. üé¨‚ú®

### Prerequisites ‚öôÔ∏èüîó

#### AIRTABLE
- Create and connect your Airtable account using a **Personal Access Token**.
- Create a table with the following columns:
  - **Deal Name** - Short representation of each record.
  - **Client Name** - Name of the client/customer.
  - **Client Email** - Email of the client/customer.
  - **Status** - Status of the deal (Draft, Approved for Invoicing, Invoiced).
  - **QuickBooks Customer ID** - ID of the client in QuickBooks.
  - **Stripe Customer ID** - ID of the client in Stripe.
  - **Stripe Payment Link** - Payment link from Stripe.
  - **QuickBooks Invoice #** - Invoice number from QuickBooks.
  - **Stripe Price Id** - Price ID of the product selected by the client in Stripe.
  - **Quantity** - Quantity of the product selected by the client.
  - **QuickBooks Product Name** - Name of the product from QuickBooks.
  - **Created** - Created timestamp.

- Select the base and table in the **Airtable Trigger** node.
- Connect and select the same base and table in all required Airtable nodes.

#### QUICKBOOKS
- Create and connect credentials using **OAuth2 authorization** in QuickBooks.
- Use the same credentials across all QuickBooks nodes.
- Add your company ID in the URL in the **Get all Quickbook products** node

#### STRIPE
- Generate and connect your Stripe account using the **Secret Key**.
- Use these credentials in all required Stripe nodes.

### Get in Touch

Please feel free to reachout to us, if you need any help in settin up this workflow.

We can also help customize workflow pet the use-case. 

Reach out us at: getstarted@intuz.com

Website: https://www.intuz.com/

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
